cardinfo.title: Salmon
cardinfo.text1: Salmon is the common name for several species of ray-finned fish in the family Salmonidae. Other fish in the same family include trout, char, grayling, and whitefish.
cardinfo.text2: Eosalmo driftwoodensis, the oldest known salmon in the fossil record, helps scientists figure how the different species of salmon diverged from a common ancestor.
cardinfo.text3: Fossil record indicate that salmon divergence occurred long before the glaciers (of Quaternary glaciation) began their cycle of advance and retreat.

cardinfo.title: Habitat
cardinfo.text1: Salmon are native to tributaries of the North Atlantic and Pacific Ocean. salmon have been introduced into non-native environments such as the Great Lakes of North America and Patagonia.
cardinfo.text2: Typically, salmon are anadromous: they hatch in fresh water, migrate to the ocean, then return to fresh water to reproduce.
cardinfo.text3: However, populations of several species are restricted to fresh water throughout their lives. A portion of a returning salmon run may stray and spawn in different freshwater systems.

cardinfo.title: Captive
cardinfo.text1: Salmon fish farming started on an experimental level in the 1960s, but became an industry in Norway in the 1980s, and in Chile in the 1990s.
cardinfo.text2: The farmed salmon industry has grown substantially in the past 40 years, and today approximately 60% of salmon produced worldwide is farmed.
cardinfo.text3: Most salmon farms hold more than one-half million fish penned in open net-cages, mostly Atlantic salmon. There are over 100 open net-cage farms There are over 100 open net-cage farms.

cardinfo.title: Prepared
cardinfo.text1: Salmon is a popular food. Classified as an oily fish, salmon is considered to be healthy due to the fish's high protein, high omega-3 fatty acids, and high vitamin D content.
cardinfo.text2: Salmon can be eaten as raw, cold and hot smoked, canned. To the Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast, salmon is considered a vital part of the diet.
cardinfo.text3: Salmon flesh is generally orange to red, although white-fleshed wild salmon with white-black skin colour occurs. The natural colour of salmon results from carotenoid pigments, astaxanthin, also canthaxanthin.
